description: group of 36 male and female figures seated and reclining in various positions, and looking in different directions; some are grinning, others look bemused
markings: center R edge: 煉心窟 {Renshinkutsu} | 三信 {Sanshin}
signed: R edge center: 孤邨藤原三信写 {Koson Fujiwara Sanshin utsusu}
text: The throng of figures on this two-panel screen is identifiable as the so-called “Thirty-Six Immortal Poets,” recognized as paragons of classical Japanese poetry already in the tenth century. The left panel features eighteen poets, while the right features only seventeen. A thirty-sixth figure, Saigū no Nyōgo—one of five female poets in the group—is hidden behind a curtain at upper right. Ikeda Koson’s composition is based on a seventeenth century original by Ōgata Kōrin, a prominent artist of the Rinpa school of Japanese painting, highlighted in this exhibition in Gallery 219.
title: Thirty-Six Immortal Poets
